headline: Police Complaint Data Shows A Broken Accountability Process

altHeadlines.value: The fundamental truths behind how complaints are processed by police departments
How race plays a role in police complaints.
How officer complaints are investigated: a case study for Philadelphia police
The outcomes of citizen complaints about police officers
How police officer complaints by citizens are processed

intro.value: In the current wake of police violence, protestors are demanding stronger accountability for officer conduct and misuse of force. In many cities, this accountability is partly served by the people’s ability to make formal complaints about police behavior.

Police complaints by citizens, ranging from physical abuse to unprofessional conduct, rarely result in consequences for officers. Concrete data is rare among departments, but in 2017, the Philadelphia Police Department became one of the few to report on every officer complaint it received. The patterns found in Philadelphia clarify many of the anecdotal observations across departments throughout the country, especially when it comes to racial disparities (e.g., complaints of White officers by Black civilians).
This is a real complaint about verbal abuse, one among 10,000+ complaints dating back to 2013.

sampleComplaint1: Philadelphia’s public data hides the identities of those involved, but records include the race and gender of the officer and person filing the complaint.

sampleComplaint2.value: While complaint investigations in some cities are conducted by civilian oversight boards, investigations in Philadelphia are conducted by the police department’s Internal Affairs division.
In the case of this complaint, the investigation, like all complaints in Philadelphia, is conducted behind closed doors and much of the decision-making process is hidden from public view.
This complaint’s investigation by police of the officer’s alleged verbal abuse yielded an outcome of no sustained findings, legalese for not enough evidence to back up the citizen’s complaint.

sunburst1.value: This outcome is common. The police department concludes “not sustained” in an overwhelming majority of cases. In the seven years of available data, just 16% of complaints have a sustained finding—meaning the police department believed there was enough evidence to support the citizen’s complaint.

This aligns with studies from other police departments, where the sustained rate can range from 6 to 20 percent. While officer complaints in Philadelphia are investigated by police, some evidence suggests that investigations involving a civilian oversight board are more likely to result in sustained findings.

sunburst2.value: Sustained complaints, however, do not immediately result in punishment for officers. Cases are first passed to an officer’s commander.

The officer’s commander can make a disciplinary decision on their own. The officer’s commander can also pass the complaint to the Police Board of Inquiry for a disciplinary hearing, composed of  three members of the police department who make a recommendation. Their recommendation  is reviewed by the Police Commissioner for a final decision on disciplinary action.

Only 2 percent of complaints, or 218 of the 11,107 complaints since 2013, resulted in punishment via a guilty finding, meaning the officer was reprimanded, terminationed, suspended, or criminal charged (the data doesn’t make any distinctions among these outcomes).

sunburst3.value: In line with decades of prior research, race correlates strongly with guilty outcomes.
For example, when a complaint is made by a white civilian, guilty findings increase from 2 to 3 percent.

sunburst4.value: While complaints by Black civilians are far more common in Philadelphia, guilty rates more than halve to 1.3 percent (compared to 3 percent for white civilians), underscoring the disparities in which Black communities are policed and a particular lack of accountability for officer actions.

sunburst5.value: This guilty finding rate shrinks even further for complaints filed against white officers. Just 22 of the 3,698, or 0.6 percent, of complaints against white officers filed by Black complainants result in a guilty finding. White officers are consistently less likely to face disciplinary action than their peers.

sunburst6.value: Conversely, complaints by white civilians against Black officers have one of the highest rate of guilty findings of 3.8 percent, underscoring that the complaint process is not only more dismissive towards Black complainants, but more punitive towards Black officers.

tilechart1.value: This visual represents each disciplinary investigation as a single square.

tilechart2.value: As of 2019, Philadelphia began redacting full details of complaints and replacing them with boilerplate 1 to 2 sentence summaries. Full summaries for complaints before July 2018 are provided, courtesy of Philly Declaration's Police Accountability Project, which published datasets before the city began redacting summaries.

tilechart3.value: Here, the complaints have been color coded based on the number of known prior complaints for the involved officer, based publicly-available data since 2013 (officers could have additional complaints from 2012 or earlier). Like many other cities, a small group of officers in Philadelphia account for a disproportionate number of complaints. Over a dozen officers, recently identified, have been involved in ten or more publicly-disclosed complaints.

tilechart4.value: Here, the investigations have been filtered to include only those involving "Physical Abuse", which include complaints filed in response to an officer’s use of force. As rare as guilty findings are in general, they’re even more rare in these investigations. Just 5 of 1493, or 0.3 percent, physical abuse investigations resulted in guilty findings while just 23, or 1.5 percent, have resulted in any kind of sustained finding Prior research involving other departments has found similar patterns.

conclusion.value: Philadelphia provides more publicly accessible data on police complaints and officer-involved shootings than almost any other major U.S. city. It is an important first step in holding police departments accountable, yet complaint summaries are redacted, disciplinary decision processes remain vague, and anonymized IDs replace the names of officers with more than a dozen recorded complaints. The lack of meaningful civilian review makes the investigative and disciplinary processes even more opaque. In order to hold institutions accountable, data and processes must not only be public, but also transparent.

method.value: All complaint and disciplinary data since 2015 came from the City of Philadelphia Open Data Portal. Pre-2015 data came from Philly Declaration's Police Accountability Project. Note that some investigations/complaints present in the original dataset were excluded from the visualizations if they lacked information on outcomes or involved officers. U.S. Census Bureau data was used to approximate police district median income, population, and demographics by combining census tracts.
